1 Flow Matching and Diffusion This section explores flow matching and diffusion models based on the MIT lecture series. Also see lecture notes (Holderrieth and Erives 2025) and materials. More advanced, supplemental proofs are referenced from (Li 2025). Modeling We presume an underlying, generally unknown, data distribution \(p_{\mathrm{data}}\) supported on \(\mathbb R^d\). Dataset consists of finite samples \(\{z_1, \dots, z_N\}\sim p_{\mathrm{data}}\), effectively yielding an empirical distribution \(\hat p_{\mathrm{data}}\). Unconditional generation consists of (1) estimating \(p_{\mathrm{data}}\) from \(\hat p_{\mathrm{data}}\), then drawing samples from the estimate. Assuming a joint distribution with some conditioning variable \(y\sim p_y\), conditional distribution consists of sampling from the conditional distribution \(p(\cdot \mid y)\). In flow models, we model the data via a mapping \(u:\mathbb R^d	o \mathbb R^d\) between standard Gaussian initial distribution \(p_{\mathrm{init}}=\mathcal N(0, I_d)\) and the data distribution. This mapping is modeled as a flow whose time-derivative is parameterized by a deep model. Given a vector field \[ (X_t, t)\mapsto u_t(X_t) \quad 	ext{of type}\quad u_{(\cdot)}(\cdot): \mathbb R^d	imes \mathbb R	o \mathbb R^d \] Treating the vector field \(u_t\) as an integrable operator, the flow \(\Phi_t: \mathbb R^d	o \mathbb R^d\) is obtained by integrating the vector field from \(0\) to time \(t\): \[ \Phi_t(x_0) = \exp \left[\int_0^t u_	au\, d	auight]x_0 \, \iff \partial_{t} \Phi_t(x_0) = u_t\left[\Phi_t(x_0)ight] \] Such model above have deterministic dynamics, i.e. once \(x_0\sim p_{\mathrm{init}}\) is fixed, the sample is fixed. We may instead consider stochastic dynamics: \[ dX_t = u_t(X_t)\, dt + \sigma_t\, dW_t \iff \Phi_t(x_0) = \exp \left[ \int_0^t u_	au \, d	au + \int_0^t \sigma_	au \, dW_	au ight] x_0 \] where \(W_t\) is the standard Brownian motion. This concludes our specification of generation procedure as a function of model parameters \(	heta\) and \(\sigma_t\). To generate a new data sample from our model: Sample \(\epsilon\sim p_{\mathrm{init}}\). Compute \(x_1 = \Phi_1(x_0=\epsilon) = \exp \left[ \int_0^1 u_	au \, d	au + \int_0^1 \sigma^t_	au \, dW_	au ight] \epsilon\) using SDE approximation methods. Training procedure The next order of business is to train \(	heta\) so that \(x_1=\Phi_1(p_{\mathrm{init}})=\approx p_{\mathrm{data}}\). The main idea is to integrate tractable conditional solutions to obtain the full, marginalized solution. Definition 1.1 (conditional Gaussian probability path) Consider a single point \(z\in \mathbb R^d\), the following Gaussian probability path continuously collapses \(p_{\mathrm{init}}\) to \(\delta_z\): \[ p_t(\cdot\mid z) = \mathcal N(\alpha_t z,  eta_t^2 I_d) \] where \(\alpha_t,  eta_t\) are noise schedulers satisfying \(\alpha_0= eta_1=0\) and \(\alpha_1= eta_0=1\). Conditional to marginal The following theorem is the main tool for converting conditional models into marginal ones. Theorem 1.3 (marginalization trick) Fixing \(p_{\mathrm{data}}\) and conditional probability paths \(p_t(\cdot\mid z)\) interpolating between \(p_{\mathrm{init}}\) and \(\delta_z\) (e.g. definition 1.1). For each \(z\in \mathbb R^d\) let \(u^*_t(\cdot\mid z):\mathbb R^d	o \mathbb R^d\) denote a vector field which realizes the conditional probability path, i.e.  \[ \exp \left[ \int_0^t u^*_	au(\cdot\mid z)\, d	au \, d	au ight]\, (\epsilon \sim p_{\mathrm{init}}) \sim p_t(\cdot \mid z) \] Then the marginal vector field defined as follows \[ u_t(x) \equiv \int u_t^*(x\mid z) p_t(z\mid x)\, dz, \quad p_t(z\mid x) = \dfrac{p_t(x\mid z) p_{\mathrm{data}}(z)}{p_t(x)} \] realizes the marginal probability distribution \[ \exp \left[ \int_0^t u^*_	au\, d	au ight]\, (\epsilon \sim p_{\mathrm{init}}) \sim p_t = \int p_t(\cdot\mid z)\, dz \] Bibliography
